Dow Jones Factiva

 Dow Jones
SE Opinion
HD Bob Hepburn: Top 10 winners and losers of 2018
BY Bob Hepburn
WC 1278 words
PD 19 December 2018
SN The Toronto Star
SC TOR
PG 0
LA English
CY Copyright (c) 2018 The Toronto Star

LP 

As 2018 draws rapidly to an end, it's time once again to reflect on the people and events in Canada that made headlines over the past 12 months.

In that tradition, here's my 11th annual list of winners and losers from across the country. As always, some big names didn't make the cut because the competition was so fierce.

TD 

First, the winners:

1. Doug Ford: It took the sudden resignation of Conservative leader Patrick Brown and Ford's curious victory in the Tory leadership contest, despite winning fewer total votes and fewer ridings than Christine Elliott, but Ford is now Ontario's premier[https://www.thestar.com/news/queenspark/2018/06/07/doug-ford-on-track-to-be-ontarios-next-premier.html].

Read more: Opinion | Martin Regg Cohn: Doug Ford is winning on the promise to shake things up[https://www.thestar.com/opinion/star-columnists/2018/06/01/doug-ford-is-winning-on-the-promise-to-shake-things-up.html]

2. Pot: The recreational weed made headlines around the world when it became legal to buy cannabis[https://www.thestar.com/cannabis.html] across Canada in what the New York Times called our “national experiment.”

Read more: Ontario passes pot bill 17 hours after marijuana legalized across Canada[https://www.thestar.com/news/cannabis/2018/10/17/ontario-passes-pot-bill-16-hours-after-marijuana-legalized-across-canada.html]

3. Donna Strickland: This University of Waterloo professor was awarded the Nobel Prize[https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2018/10/05/its-just-been-crazy-donna-strickland-describes-aftermath-of-nobel-prize-win.html] in Physics for groundbreaking work in laser physics that she did while she was a graduate student some 30 years ago.

Read more: Canadian 'laser jock' Donna Strickland becomes third woman to win Nobel physics prize[https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2018/10/02/canadian-donna-strickland-third-woman-to-win-nobel-physics-prize.html]

4. Hockey sticks: By placing hockey sticks outside their front doors[https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2018/04/09/the-boys-might-need-it-wherever-they-are-hockey-sticks-out-jerseys-on-for-humboldt-bronco-victims.html], people across Canada came together in a moving display of sympathy and support for the families of Humboldt junior hockey team members who died when their bus collided with a truck in rural Saskatchewan.

Read more: Opinion | Editorial: A fitting memorial for the Humboldt Broncos[https://www.thestar.com/opinion/editorials/2018/08/02/a-fitting-memorial-for-the-humboldt-broncos.html]

5. Lyneth Mann-Lewis: This Brampton mother never gave up hope of seeing her son, Jermaine, again after he was allegedly abducted 31 years ago. But after a decades-long search, she was finally reunited with him[https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2018/10/30/how-a-retired-cops-unrelenting-resolve-tracked-down-a-brampton-mothers-son-31-years-later.html]. “Believe that all things are possible,” she said as tears of streamed down her face.

Read more: 'Your son is alive, we've found him': Brampton mom reunites with son 31 years after father allegedly stole him, took him to the U.S.[https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2018/10/29/mother-and-son-reunited-31-years-after-alleged-parental-abduction-to-speak-this-afternoon-at-toronto-police-hq.html]

6. Amanda Simard: The rookie Ontario MPP courageously stood up[https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2018/11/29/rebel-mpp-amanda-simard-quits-tories-over-french-cuts.html] for her Franco-Ontarian constituents when she quit the Conservative party caucus over cuts by Doug Ford to French-language services, saying she felt as if she had been “spit in my face.” (See Caroline Mulroney under Losers).

Read more: Simard says Tories 'betrayed' her with cuts to French-language services[https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2018/12/03/tories-rush-to-raise-official-party-status-bar-amid-fears-of-simard-defecting-to-liberals.html]

7. Mikael Kingsbury: The 26-year-old from Quebec, the greatest moguls freestyle skier in history, won the Lou Marsh Award[https://www.thestar.com/sports/2018/12/11/mikael-kingsbury-wins-lou-marsh-trophy-as-canadas-top-athlete-of-2018.html] as Canada's top athlete after capturing an Olympic gold medal and increasing his World Cup victories to an amazing 51.

Read more: Opinion | Bruce Arthur: Lou Marsh Trophy goes to Mikael Kingsbury, and he deserves it[https://www.thestar.com/sports/2018/12/11/lou-marsh-trophy-goes-to-mikael-kingsbury-and-he-deserves-it.html]

8. Viola Desmond: This Nova Scotia civil rights activist who died in 1965 is once again an inspiration for all after she became the first woman other than the Queen and the first Black person to be featured on a regularly circulating Canadian banknote — a $10 bill[https://www.thestar.com/halifax/2018/11/19/halifax-community-celebrates-new-10-bill-in-honour-of-civil-rights-icon-viola-desmond.html].

Read more: Viola Desmond celebrated in song and prayer, but Halifax crowd reminded 'we have a very long way to go'[https://www.thestar.com/halifax/2018/11/25/viola-desmond-celebrated-in-song-and-prayer-but-halifax-crowd-reminded-we-have-a-very-long-way-to-go.html]

9. Drake: The Toronto musician had the world's most-streamed album and song of the year with Scorpion and “God's Play, earning 8.2 billion streams (no, that's not a typo, 8.2 BILLION).

Read more: Drake sings praises of Toronto onstage: 'this is how the world is supposed to work'[https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/2018/08/22/drake-sings-praises-of-toronto-onstage-this-is-how-the-world-is-supposed-to-work.html]

10. Long-suffering Leaf fans: After 51 years of frustration since their favourite team last won the Stanley Cup, loyal fans have hope the dought may be over following the signing of star forward John Tavares[http://Kyle%20Dubas%E2%80%99%20signing%20of%20John%20Tavares%20worth%20every%20penny%20for%20Maple%20Leafs] — but it's a long, long season.

Read more: Opinion | Rosie DiManno: John Tavares thriving in the fish bowl that is the Toronto Maple Leafs[https://www.thestar.com/sports/leafs/opinion/2018/11/19/john-tavares-thriving-in-the-fish-bowl-that-is-the-toronto-maple-leafs.html]

And now the losers:

1. Tony Clement: This long-time Conservative, who at times dreamed of being prime minister, saw his political future go up in flames[https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2018/11/06/conservative-mp-tony-clement-steps-back-from-duties-over-extortion.html] when he was kicked out of the federal Tory caucus after being caught in a sexting/extortion scandal.

Read more: Opinion | Susan Delacourt: With his sexting adventures, Clement has got himself into three kinds of trouble[https://www.thestar.com/politics/political-opinion/2018/11/07/with-his-sexting-adventures-clement-has-got-himself-into-three-kinds-of-trouble.html]

2. Drunk curlers: A team of elite Canadian curlers, including an Olympic champion[https://www.thestar.com/sports/2018/11/21/ryan-fry-to-take-indefinite-leave-from-team-brad-jacobs-after-being-kicked-out-of-world-curling-tour-event.html], were kicked out of a world tournament in Red Deer, Alta., for being too disruptive and “too drunk to curl.” Who knew curlers liked to drink?

Read more: 'Too drunk' foursome tossed out of World Curling Tour event in Alberta[https://www.thestar.com/edmonton/2018/11/19/boozing-before-game-leads-to-teams-ejection-from-world-curling-tour-event.html]

3. Caroline Mulroney: Despite wishful thinking by some Conservatives that the Ontario attorney general will be a major force in 2019, her performance this past year[https://www.thestar.com/opinion/star-columnists/2018/09/12/where-are-you-caroline-mulroney.html] of bowing to Doug Ford's actions in slashing francophone services and threatening to use notwithstanding clause to force through his cuts to Toronto council, as well as her flip-flopping on her views on a carbon tax to match those of Ford, tells a different story.

Read more: Opinion | Bob Hepburn: The dream dies for Caroline Mulroney[https://www.thestar.com/opinion/star-columnists/2018/11/28/the-dream-dies-for-caroline-mulroney.html]

4. Bombardier: Not only did the maker of[https://www.thestar.com/topic.bombardier.html] the new Toronto streetcars continue to miss delivery deadlines, but 67 of the 89 cars delivered by mid-year had to be taken out of service[https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2018/07/10/bombardier-president-apologizes-to-ttc-and-riders-for-streetcar-flaws.html] for repairs.

Read more: Opinion | David Olive: Has Bombardier finally run out of track?[https://www.thestar.com/business/opinion/2018/12/17/has-bombardier-finally-run-out-of-track.html]

5. Frank and Belinda Stronach: In Canada's own version of Family Feud[https://www.thestar.com/business/2018/11/05/stronach-family-feud-deepens-as-brother-joins-the-fray.html], the Toronto billionaire auto-parts manufacturer is suing his daughter and others, including two grandchildren, for $520 million for alleged mismanagement of assets and trust funds — and you thought your family had troubles.

Read more: Frank Stronach sues his daughter Belinda alleging mismanagement of assets and trust funds[https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2018/10/10/frank-stronach-sues-his-daughter-belinda-alleging-mismanagement-of-assets-and-trust-funds.html]

6. Bus riders: Greyhound Canada ended its passenger services from Northern Ontario and across Western Canada[https://www.thestar.com/vancouver/2018/07/19/for-rural-and-northern-bc-no-bus-means-no-options.html], leaving thousands of intercity bus riders scrambling to find alternative ways to travel.

Read more: What it's like to ride the Greyhound for 27 hours, through three provinces and 55 stops[https://www.thestar.com/edmonton/2018/07/19/what-its-like-to-ride-the-greyhound-for-27-hours-three-provinces-and-55-stops.html]

7. TSX: Canada's main stock market index is closing the year near its lowest point in more than two years, resulting in huge losses for millions of Canadian investors.

Read more: TSX sets new two-year low as price of oil falls to lowest level since fall 2017[https://www.thestar.com/business/2018/12/17/industrials-sector-weighs-on-toronto-stock-market-us-markets-mixed.html]

8. Julie Payette: The Governor General insists all's well, but she has proven a disappointment[https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2018/09/30/its-not-easy-being-gg-payette-tries-to-reassure-staff-as-criticism-of-her-mounts.html] with fewer trips, speeches and events than her predecessors. She even declined to accept daffodils from cancer patients.

Read more: Gov. Gen. Julie Payette faces questions over her workload and schedule[https://www.thestar.com/politics/federal/2018/09/23/gov-gen-julie-payette-faces-questions-over-her-workload-and-schedule.html]

9. Ontario students: Doug Ford cuts millions in funding[https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2018/12/18/students-to-lose-jobs-after-ford-government-axes-school-programs.html] for programs that support students, including after-school jobs for needy teens, special tutors, supports for racialized youth and more. A government “For the People,” eh?

Opinion | Premier Ford's troublesome track record[https://www.thestar.com/opinion/contributors/2018/12/17/premier-fords-troublesome-track-record.html]

10. Kathleen Wynne: She led the Ontario Liberals[https://www.thestar.com/topic.kathleen_wynne.html] to the party's worst defeat ever[https://www.thestar.com/news/queenspark/2018/06/07/sombre-mood-in-kathleen-wynnes-riding-of-don-valley-west.html], failing to buck the “time-for-change” mood of voters.

Read more: 'We lost our way,' Ontario Liberal leader tells party members at election post-mortem[https://www.thestar.com/news/queenspark/2018/09/29/ontarios-interim-liberal-leader-john-fraser-said-the-party-is-confronting-some-harsh-truths.html]

Bob Hepburn is a politics columnist based in Toronto. Follow him on Twitter: @BobHepburn[https://twitter.com/BobHepburn]


ART 
Hockey stick sits on the front porch of a house in Humboldt, Sask., on April 9, 2018. Social media users reached out to the Saskatchewan town of Humboldt, sharing photos of hockey sticks left on front porches to pay tribute to the 16 lives lost after a bus carrying the Broncos junior hockey team collided with a semi truck. Thirteen others were injured.

NS

RE

PUB 
Toronto Star Newspapers Limited

AN

HD A look at CP's end-of-year coverage plans
CR The Canadian Press 
WC 3919 words
PD 19 December 2018
ET 11:24 AM
SN The Canadian Press
SC CPR
LA English
CY (c) 2018 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.

LP 

EDITORS: As usual, The Canadian Press is working on a robust package of thoughtful stories to keep your newspages and websites ticking over the slow holiday period. Here is an updated list of stories we are working on. Dates are subject to change. If you have questions you can email managing editor Andrea Baillie (andrea.baillie@thecanadianpress.com[mailto:andrea.baillie@thecanadianpress.com]) Deputy Western bureau chief Tim Cook (tim.cook@thecanadianpress.com[mailto:tim.cook@thecanadianpress.com]).

Thursday, Dec. 20

TD 

Canadian Press Business newsmaker of the year.

YEAR-HKO-Bus-Crash-Seatbelts: UNDATED -- One of the big legacies coming out of the Humboldt Broncos crash was a movement to see seatbelts on buses. Here is a look at how the crash has teams buckling up across the country. By Colette Derworiz.

YEAR-Sports-Sizzling-Summer: UNDATED -- It's set to be a huge year for Canada's summer athletes. With the 2020 Tokyo Olympics around the corner, the 2019 summer schedule is jam packed with qualifiers and major international events, including the Women's World Cup, the Pan Am Games, the world track and field championships and the world aquatic championships. By Lori Ewing

YEAR-Ont-Municipalities-Pot: TORONTO -- The Ontario government has given municipalities until late January to decide whether they want to opt out of hosting brick-and-mortar pot shops within their boundaries. Some communities have already signaled they want no cannabis retail outlets, while others have yet to make up their minds. By Paola Loriggio.

YEAR-WEA-Top-Stories: UNDATED — A look at the Top 10 weather stories of the year. By Bob Weber.

Friday, Dec. 21

YEAR-Canadian-Politics: OTTAWA -- A look at federal politics as we head into an election year. By Joan Bryden.

YEAR-Grocery-ECommerce: Shifting consumer expectations continue to force grocers to change into technologically savvy destinations for time-strapped shoppers. Canadian grocers doubled down on expanding their e-commerce offerings and incorporating sit-down restaurants into their spaces this year. With grocerants and home delivery now on tap, what will the grocery store look like in a year, or in a decade? By Aleksandra Sagan.

YEAR-Sports-Bell-Rogers: UNDATED -- It might be the most important storyline in Canadian sports. With so many sporting properties owned by Bell or Rogers, the decisions of those companies loom large across the country. We take a look at what transpired in 2018 and what to watch for in 2019. By Gregory Strong

Sunday, Dec. 23

YEAR-Desk-Phones-Phaseout: TORONTO -- It's time to say goodbye to the clunky desk phone and inefficient voicemail: how office environments are modernizing the workplace. By Victoria Ahearn. VIDEO.

YEAR-Checkout-Tech: Retailers are dabbling in handheld or phone-based self-checkout, but many are disappointed in the response from customers so far. We'll take a look at the different technologies and see which ones are and aren't working, and why. By Tara Deschamps.

YEAR-Outdoors-Diversity: UNDATED -- A recent ad campaign by Mountain Equipment Co-op drew fire for featuring only white people, but is there diversity when it comes to people using Canada's backcountry. Parks Canada is trying to attract a more diverse visitor base, but using signage that focuses more on symbols that English and French. By Colette Derworiz.

YEAR-RELIGION-Church-Planting: UNDATED -- As churches struggle with empty pews and disinterested congregants, one organization is trying to make keeping the faith more appealing by creating new evangelical congregations through a process known as "church planting." The Grace Network in Toronto describes Canada as a post-Christian nation, with decades of church decline, and has set out to combat the problem. We talk with the group and someone who has "planted" a church with them about the challenges facing Canadian churches and the techniques being used to grow Christianity today. By Nicole Thompson.

YEAR-Old-Settlement-Unearthed: QUEBEC -- Canada isn't exactly Rome when it comes to ruins, so when construction workers in Quebec City recently uncovered 325-year-old remnants of the earliest European settlement it caused a stir. We talk to historians and archeologists about why they are so excited by this wooden palisade, and what else remains to be discovered. Mayor Regis Labeaume joked that he won't be satisfied until they find Champlain's tomb, but that is likely lost forever. By Morgan Lowrie.

Monday, Dec. 24

YEAR-Centre-Block-Closing: OTTAWA -- Centre Block on Parliament Hill is closing, and politics as we know it will have to adjust. By Joan Bryden

YEAR-Invasive-Species: UNDATED -- Just a year or two ago scientists were crowing about the leaps made in protecting endangered frogs in B.C.'s East Kootenay. The endangered northern leopard frogs were multiplying in a positive direction until the bull frogs muscled in, swallowing up years of work. From carp and mussels in Canada's waterways to hogweed and purple loosestrife in the ditches, Canada is being threatened by an invasion of species that can ruin industry or recreation and costs government's millions to fight. By Terri Theodore

Tuesday, Dec. 25

YEAR-Indigenous-Resource: Indigenous communities that embrace resource development are rewarded with rising incomes, according to a recent Montreal Economic Institute study. So what are the motivations of First Nations that oppose oil, forestry, mining and other pursuits? How do they earn a buck? By Ian Bickis.

YEAR-HKO-Bus-Crash-Organ-Donations: UNDATED -- There was a spike in organ donations follow the Humboldt Broncos bus crash. We catch up with Logan Boulet's family and the people he helped with his donation. What ever happened to presumed consent? By Colette Derworiz.

Wednesday, Dec. 26

Canadian Press female athlete of the year. VIDEO.

YEAR-Cancer-Love: TORONTO -- We profile the love stories of young people who fought cancer and how this impacted their relationship. By Adina Bresge. VIDEO.

YEAR-Retirement-Fake-Out: TORONTO -- Musicians weigh in on when — if ever — it's time to retire, and why we often see many last-ever tours. By David Friend.

YEAR-Sask-Politics: REGINA -- Since replace Brad Wall, Saskatchewan Premier Scott Moe has used his opposition against the federal carbon tax as a major front in the battle to define his leadership. A yearend interview with the premier. By Ryan McKenna.

YEAR-Pot-Plant-Lifecycle: How does a marijuana plant go from seedling to final product? We'll go behind the scenes to look at the lifecycle of a pot plant. By Armina Ligaya. VIDEO.

YEAR-Cashless-Society-Panhandling: UNDATED -- As more people use cards to pay for everything they buy, how are those who rely on cash coping. For people living on the street and buskers, the decline of cash must be a worry and changing their lives in a fundamental way. We talk to those who rely on the goodwill of strangers, and experts on what might replace this form of giving in the future. By Dirk Meissner

Thursday, Dec. 27

Canadian Press male athlete of the year. VIDEO.

YEAR-Canadian-Economy: OTTAWA -- A look at the economy in 2018, and where it's heading in 2019. By Andy Blatchford.

YEAR-Markets: Round up of market performance for the year and crystal ball forecasts for 2019. Will bull market finally end? By Ross Marowits.

YEAR-Mba-Politics: WINNIPEG -- A yearend interview with Manitoba Premier Brian Pallister and a story on the state of Manitoba politics. By Steve Lambert.

YEAR-Glaciers-Disappearing: UNDATED -- Canada's glaciers are disappearing. A report earlier this year said they're receding even faster than experts predicted with a warning climate. What will Canada look like when the ice shields shrink and what are the consequences? By Hina Alma.

YEAR-Maxime-Bernier: MONTREAL -- Maxime Bernier is sometimes mocked in his home province for his unorthodox positions on everything from corporate taxes to pipelines. He is gambling that in 2019 he can persuade enough Canadians -- including Quebecers -- to vote for a straight-talking "smart populist." By Giuseppe Valiante.

YEAR-Victoria-Council-Refugee: VICTORIA -- In last month's civic elections, Victoria voters elected Sharmurke Dubow, who arrived in the city as a refugee from Somalia and has lived much of his past life in camps after fleeing danger. He was doing refugee work in Victoria and decided to run for council. He had never voted before in his life and ends up being elected to council. By Dirk Meissner. VIDEO.

Friday, Dec. 28

Canadian Press team of the year. VIDEO.

YEAR-Federal-Green-Breakthrough: OTTAWA -- After several victories at the provincial level, including in B.C. where it holds the balance of power, Is 2019 going to be a breakthrough year for the federal Green party? By Mia Rabson

YEAR-Forestry-Supply: As climate change makes fires and insect infestations more destructive to Canada's forests, what does the supply picture look like for Canada's forestry industry? By Ian Bickis.

YEAR-Alta-Politics: EDMONTON -- The messages are being sharpened. The attacks are being honed. Alberta's political leaders are gearing up for an election in 2019. By Dean Bennett

YEAR-Toronto-Homicides: TORONTO -- It's been a rough year for the homicide squad in Canada's most populous city. Between dealing with the baffling unsolved murders of a billionaire couple, arresting an accused serial killer, grappling with the deaths of ten people in a horrific van attack, and dealing with a spate of high-profile shootings, Toronto's detectives have been stretched thin. Additionally, the number of homicides in the city are on track to hit an annual record and the force has faced accusations that it isn't doing enough to combat brazen gun crime. What is the state of the force's homicide team, what kind of support is it seeking from governments and how does it plan to tackle its challenges in the year ahead? By Liam Casey.

YEAR-Universities-Newton's-Apples: UNDATED -- Every university in the world is said to have an apple tree that is a descendant of the tree that Sir Isaac Newton sat under during his eureka moment on gravity. The University of B.C.'s Newton tree has delicious, Granny Smith-like fruit that is good for pies. We talk to some of the larger universities and ask about the trees. By Hina Alam. VIDEO.

Sunday, Dec. 30

YEAR-Holograms: TORONTO -- With the Glenn Gould hologram set to head on tour next year, a look at whether audiences actually want to see virtual stars on stage. By David Friend.

YEAR-Real-Estate: Is real estate the next industry to experience a digital revolution? Why has it taken so long? What does it mean for the real estate agent, a profession that has ballooned in popularity in the last few years. A look at technology in real estate and whether agents will ever become obsolete. By Linda Nguyen.

YEAR-Jury-Selection-Process: CALGARY -- After the Colten Boushie murder trial, which saw an all-white jury acquit a white farmer of killing an Indigenous man, the federal government said it is moving to make juries more representative. We take a look at how that is going. By Bill Graveland.

YEAR-Juror-Rules: CALGARY -- A mistrial was requested in Calgary this year because guards let a jury go to Denny's for a drink after a particularly graphic trial. Here is a look at what you can expect if you ever have to sit on a jury. By Lauren Krugel.

YEAR-BASE-Jumpers: UNDATED -- A college dropout from Ottawa who travelled across Canada, built himself a treehouse in Whistler and became an elite BASE jumper died on a wingsuit flight in Switzerland this year. He was 38. He may be gone but his legacy lives on. Other BASE jumpers have been scattering his ashes at locations around the world on what they call "ash jumps." We look at the little-known world of BASE jumping, one of the world's most extreme adventure sports. By Liam Casey.

Monday, Dec. 31

YEAR-Diary: UNDATED _ An in-brief look at some of the most significant news events of the last 12 months, in chronological order. Moves online. Previous version moved online out on Dec. 11.

YEAR-MUSIC-Quebec-Scene: UNDATED -- Quebec's music scene, such a powerful force for change in the '60s and '70s, has recently become all too predictable, with new stars pumped out of formulaic TV talent shows and old stars clinging on. But there are signs of change as a new generation turns its back on the conservative establishment. The androgynous Hubert Lenoir dominated this year's ADISQ awards and Safia Nolin has become a success despite refusing to conform to norms of what a woman pop star should look like. We introduce Canadians to the new faces trying to shake up Quebec music. By Giuseppe Valiante.

YEAR-Brain-Opioids VANCOUVER — Dayton Wilson's drug-taking routine ended when he overdosed on heroin laced with fentanyl, but being able to walk and talk normally are also part of his past as he struggles with brain damage from a drug that is linked to thousands of deaths. Wilson, 24, overdosed in Vancouver's Downtown Eastside in August 2016, but he doesn't remember the exact date or being transported to hospital, where he would spend two months before being able to take a few steps or utter some words. Health experts say that while data on overdose deaths are being collected across Canada, brain injuries among those who survive the effects of illicit opioids must also be tracked in order to provide people with resources such as speech and occupational therapy so they become as functional as possible. By Camille Bains.

Tuesday, Jan. 1

YEAR-SOC-Free-Footie: EDMONTON -- Alphonso Davies's has shone a spotlight on an Edmonton program called Free Footie, which aims to let less fortunate kids play soccer. Beckie Scott has a similar program to bring cross-country skiing to kids on Alberta reserves. By Colette Derworiz.

YEAR-Prescribing-Arts: TORONTO -- A growing number of doctors are prescribing visits to museums and art galleries, but what does the science say? By Sheryl Ubelacker.

Wednesday, Jan. 2

YEAR-Pet-First-Aid: CALGARY -- Is Fido choking? I think Fluffy is having a heart attack. A Calgary company is offering a first aid course for pet owners. By Bill Graveland.

Thursday, Jan. 3

YEAR-Opioid-Crisis: VANCOUVER -- Your chances of surviving an opioid overdose may depend on where you live in Canada. Some provinces have numerous safe consumption sites while others have none. Naloxone kits are free for most in six provinces or territories but that's not the case in others, indicating the patchwork of services across Canada. Canada's big city mayors and other experts have called for a national plan to stop the dying but so far there's no umbrella approach from the federal government. By Amy Smart.

STORIES THAT HAVE ALREADY MOVED

MOVED Monday, Dec. 3

YEAR-PEI-Politics: CHARLOTTETOWN -- Tiny P.E.I. has long embraced the politically unusual — it had the first premier of non-European heritage, the first elected woman premier, the first openly gay male premier. Now, polls suggest it could elect Canada's first Green premier. As Greens celebrate incremental gains elsewhere, they lead the polls on the Island ahead of next year's elections. By Michael MacDonald.

MOVED Thursday, Dec. 6

YEAR-Problematic-Books: TORONTO -- Authors discuss whether classic works that address racism should be replaced with more diverse voices. By Adina Bresge.

MOVED Monday, Dec. 10

YEAR-Presents-Delayed: CALGARY — A Canada Post backlog thanks to a labour dispute and Greyhound exiting a large chunk of the country are creating headaches for anyone shipping presents ahead of holidays. By Lauren Krugel.

YEAR-Edibles-Cooking: TORONTO -- Gingerbread men are a seasonal staple but the spiced treats by Vanessa Labrecque this year will be special: They'll be infused with cannabis. The avid baker says she'll be whipping up a batch of herb-spiked cookies for a special Christmas edition of her cooking-with-cannabis class in honour of Canada's first festive season post-legalization. By Cassandra Szklarski.

YEAR-Bad-Lawyers: UNDATED -- Several new Canadians in the Toronto area have won civil suits against a former lawyer whose negligent practices saw them lose thousands of dollars. They nevertheless haven't seen a penny of the money owed to them after winning their cases. Their experiences have raised questions about what recourse, if any, people in such situations have. By Colin Perkel.

MOVED Tuesday, Dec. 11

YEAR-Diary: UNDATED — An in-brief look at some of the most significant news events of the last 12 months, in chronological order. Moves ONLINE OUT. Will be sent online Dec. 31.

YEAR-Indigenous-Films-Centre: TORONTO -- A look at a pivotal year for Indigenous films and what the future holds. By Victoria Ahearn.

YEAR-Clare's-Law: REGINA — Saskatchewan proposed the legislation in early November to try and reduce the province's high domestic violence rates. Clare's Law allows an individual to request information about a partner's abusive past from police if they believe they're at risk. By Ryan McKenna.

YEAR-Halifax-Sports-Scene: HALIFAX -- The buzz is all about a potential CFL franchise, but Halifax is already getting new sports teams. Canadian soccer and lacrosse leagues are planning squads, and that's on top of existing major junior hockey team and a National Basketball League of Canada team. Can a city of about 400,000 - albeit one that functions as a regional capital -sustain so many teams? By Brett Bundale.

YEAR-Quebec-Adoption-Laws: MONTREAL -- Quebec has lagged behind other provinces in introducing legislation that allows adoptees to locate their birth parents. But it is finally catching up, and people who gave children up for adoption face a deadline next year if they want to opt out of making their information available. Through the eyes of someone who has been waiting for years to learn their heritage and worries that time is running out, we look at Quebec's adoption changes. By Sidhartha Banerjee.

YEAR-Choir-Choir-Choir: TORONTO -- A profile of Canada's most successful hipster choir. By David Friend. VIDEO.

MOVED Wednesday, Dec. 12

YEAR-USMCA-Liberals-Election: WASHINGTON -- What will the new North American free trade pact mean for Canadian politics and the Liberals re-election hopes in October? By James McCarten.

YEAR-Lottery-Makeover: WINNIPEG -- Bigger jackpots. Electronic kiosks. Are online sales next? Lotteries are undergoing a makeover to stay relevant to younger players. By Steve Lambert.

YEAR-Real-Estate-Corrections: LANGLEY, B.C. -- Langley has been the centre of a condo boom in the last few years as buyers grabbed units as soon as or before they were built. In the last few months condo sales have dropped by half and there is three times the inventory. One developer recently sold units with free mortgage payments for a year. There are similar signs in Surrey and Abbotsford. Home prices outside of Vancouver have also fallen by as much as 30 per cent in some areas and when people owe far more than they home is worth they start walking away. Could the federal and provincial government measures too cool the market have been too successful? Is it too late to correct the correction? By Laura Kane.

MOVED Thursday, Dec. 13

YEAR-Climate-Change-Depression: UNDATED -- Is climate change making you depressed? Doctors say it is a real thing and it is becoming more and more common. By Bob Weber.

YEAR-High-Tech-Snow-Removal: MONTREAL -- Montreal is promising to introduce smart snow removal this winter, including drones to make sure the dump trucks haul snow to the right location. We'll look at how technology and green alternatives are being employed to confront the perennial Canadian problem of keeping winter streets clear. By Morgan Lowrie.

MOVED Friday, Dec. 14

YEAR-Science-Traditional-Knowledge: UNDATED -- There are increasing conflicts between science and traditional knowledge. The polar bear hunt is a good example. Scientists think the numbers are low and the hunt should be curtailed. But those who have been on the land for thousands of years say the numbers are higher than ever. By Bob Weber.

YEAR-Sports-Technology: UNDATED -- While technology certainly has helped sports develop in many areas, there also are potential problems. Social media has caused problems for some teams and athletes as they attempt to navigate through a new world. By John Chidley-Hill

MOVED Sunday, Dec. 16

Canadian Press Business news story of the year

YEAR-FOOD-Cuban-Lunch: CAMROSE, Alta. -- It's been six months since Crystal Regehr Westergard brought the nostalgic candy treat Cuban Lunch back to Canada. How has business been since? By Lauren Krugel.

MOVED Monday, Dec. 17

YEAR-Boy-Rare-Condition: ONOWAY, Alta. — Little Stanley Porter is one of about 30 people ever in the world to have a reported diagnosis of Beare-Stevenson syndrome, a rare condition that caused the bone plates in his skull to fuse together before he was born. Doctors told his parents he would likely only live a few months. But after 10 surgeries and two years of medical ups and downs, Porter is doing well. He's a big brother and an Oilers fan and loves watching "Paw Patrol." And now he's going to school. By Chris Purdy. VIDEO.

MOVED Tuesday, Dec. 18

Canadian Press news story of the year. VIDEO.

YEAR-Atlantic-Foreign-Students: ST. JOHN'S, N.L. -- Foreign students are suddenly flooding Atlantic Canada's universities — including one where they now comprise half the student population. It's sparking cultural change in a traditionally homogeneous region — and hope that immigration may help solve demographic decline. By Holly McKenzie-Sutter

MOVED Wednesday, Dec. 19

Canadian Press newsmaker of the year. VIDEO.

YEAR-US-Trump-Congress: WASHINGTON -- With the Democrats gaining control of Congress and Trump in the White House, there are bound to be fireworks ahead in American politics in 2019. By James McCarten.

YEAR-BKO-Canadian-Hoops: TORONTO -- Basketball certainly has made major strides in Canada, with the country's hopes high for strong performances on the men's and women's sides at the 2020 Olympics. But most players still are coming out of the major centres and TV ratings still aren't great. What does the sport have to do to take the next step? By Lori Ewing.

YEAR-Accessibility-Legislation: UNDATED -- Canada's first national accessibility legislation was tabled this year, aimed at improving life for those with disabilities. As it makes its way through the legislative process, however, the Accessible Canada Act has drawn mounting pushback from disability groups who say it doesn't go far enough. They point to additional layers of bureaucratic red tape and a lack of a target date for achieving accessibility as just some of the issues. By Michelle McQuigge.

YEAR-Refugees-Border-Crossing: UNDATED -- Quebec has received the large majority of refugee claimants walking across the border from the United States, and it is not a coincidence that political leaders from the province — Francois Legault and Maxime Bernier — saw political gains to be made in adopting a hard line against immigration. An Angus Reid poll in August found a significant increase in the number of Canadians saying we take in too many immigrants — about half the population. A look at whether 2019 might mark a broader turn away from the open-door approach of Justin Trudeau. By Sidhartha Banerjee.

HD The fossil fuel era is coming to an end, but the lawsuits are just beginning
BY Kyla Tienhaara
CR Canada Research Chair in Economy and Environment
WC 1088 words
PD 19 December 2018
ET 10:20 AM
SN The Canadian Press
SC CPR
LA English
CY (c) 2018 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.

LP 

This article was originally published on The Conversation, an independent and nonprofit source of news, analysis and commentary from academic experts. Disclosure information is available on the original site.

___

TD 

Author: Kyla Tienhaara, Canada Research Chair in Economy and Environment, Queen's University, Ontario

"Coal is dead."

These are not the words of a Greenpeace activist or left-wing politician, but of Jim Barry, the global head of the infrastructure investment group at Blackrock — the world's largest asset manager. Barry made this statement in 2017, but the writing has been on the wall for longer than that.

Banks know it, which is why they are increasingly unwilling to underwrite new coal mines and power plants. Unions and coal workers know it, which is why they are demanding a just transition and new employment opportunities in the clean economy. Even large diversified mining companies are getting out of the business of coal.

The only ones who seem to have remained in denial are President Donald Trump and non-diversified mining companies like Westmoreland Coal. The Denver-based firm made a bad bet in 2013 when it purchased five coal mines in Alberta. Now it wants Canadian taxpayers to pay for its mistake.

Alberta's coal phaseout

Three years ago, Alberta's New Democratic Party (NDP) committed to what some have described as "the most ambitious climate plan in North America to date." In addition to the development of an economy-wide carbon price, the province is phasing out coal-fired power by 2030. Without the infrastructure to export coal, the climate plan has also resulted in a de facto phaseout of local thermal coal mining.

To ensure support for the plan, major utility companies in the province were provided with "transition payments" to facilitate the switch to gas and renewable energy. Westmoreland did not receive a government handout, because coal mining companies have no role to play in the energy transition. The company, which filed for bankruptcy protection for its investments in the United States in October, doesn't think this is fair.

NAFTA's investment chapter

Because Westmoreland is an American company, it can rely on the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) for protection from "unfair" treatment. NAFTA allows a foreign investor to use a process known as "Investor-State Dispute Settlement" (ISDS) when government action harms its business in some way.

ISDS allows foreign investors to bypass local courts and bring claims for monetary compensation to an international tribunal. The system is not unique to NAFTA; it is found in other trade agreements like the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) and thousands of bilateral investment treaties (known as Foreign Investment Promotion and Protection Agreements in Canada).

ISDS is hugely controversial. Concerns have been raised by a wide range of actors about both the process of ISDS, and the way the system can infringe on the sovereign right of states to regulate to protect public health, human rights and the environment.

More than 900 ISDS cases have been launched by investors since the early 1990s, including 27 against Canada that have so far cost Canadian taxpayers at least $315 million. There is one ongoing dispute that concerns a ban on gas fracking in Québec, but the Westmoreland claim is the first brought in relation to a policy explicitly designed to combat climate change.

Westmoreland argues that part of the reason it invested in Canada in 2013 was to diversify its holdings in response to regulatory risk. At the time, the Obama Administration was taking action under the Clean Power Plan to reduce the reliance of American utilities on coal. The company's failure to anticipate similar regulatory action by its northern neighbour is remarkable.

A key battleground

If governments respond appropriately to the urgent warning issued by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in October, efforts to phase out fossil fuels will have to ramp up considerably — and quickly. We should expect the industry to fight these efforts through a variety of means. ISDS may become a key battleground.

The U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA or CUSMA, depending on who is talking about it), which may replace NAFTA (it has been signed, but has not been ratified), does not retain the process of ISDS between Canada and the U.S.

While this is good news in the long run, some have suggested that there will be a "rush of filings" before access to ISDS for already established investors expires (three years after USMCA comes into force). Canada will also be exposed to claims from investors under other agreements such as the CPTPP and Canada-European Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA).

Other countries, particularly poorer nations, face an even higher risk of ISDS claims and have far less resources available to fight them. It is notable that big oil companies have retained some access to ISDS against Mexico in USMCA, after lobbying hard for it.

A climate of fear?

If Westmoreland's case proceeds to arbitration, it will not have direct implications for Alberta's climate policy. An investment tribunal cannot require the provincial government to reverse the coal phaseout; it can only award the company damages. Westmoreland is asking for US$470 million. It is the federal government, rather than Alberta, that would have to pay compensation to Westmoreland if the company's claim was successful. However, Ontario did agree to pay the award in a recent NAFTA case.

What is more concerning than any potential payout is that Westmoreland's suit could hinder efforts to implement similar plans to combat climate change in other jurisdictions.

"Regulatory chill" is a phenomenon that has been observed in several jurisdictions around the world. A notable example is the decision of the New Zealand government to delay the introduction of legislation to require plain packaging of tobacco products until Australia won its ISDS case against the tobacco company Philip Morris International. This delay of regulatory action — out of fear of expensive litigation — may have cost lives.

As recent forest fires and floods have demonstrated, delays in action to combat climate change can also be deadly.

___

This article is republished from The Conversation under a Creative Commons license. Disclosure information is available on the original site. Read the original article:

https://theconversation.com/the-fossil-fuel-era-is-coming-to-an-end-but-the-lawsuits-are-just-beginning-107512[https://theconversation.com/the-fossil-fuel-era-is-coming-to-an-end-but-the-lawsuits-are-just-beginning-107512]


CO

NS

RE

IPD

PUB

AN 
Document CPR0000020181219eecj00nj9


HD Inflation slows to 1.7%, removing any interest-rate urgency for Bank of Canada
BY Andy Blatchford
CR The Canadian Press 
WC 732 words
PD 19 December 2018
ET 10:00 AM
SN The Canadian Press
SC CPR
LA English
CY (c) 2018 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.

LP 

OTTAWA — Cooling inflation has given the Bank of Canada another reason to keep interest rates on ice next month.

The annual pace of inflation slowed in November to 1.7 per cent as upward pressure from higher gasoline prices eased off, Statistics Canada said in a report Wednesday.

TD 

The agency's latest data point showed the weakest year-over-year pace of inflation since January 2018 in a reading far more sluggish than October's level of 2.4 per cent. Inflation for September was 2.2 per cent.

Canada's core inflation readings, which strip out volatile items like gasoline, also had a little less pep last month.

Many experts said the inflation results Wednesday reinforced predictions the Bank of Canada will be in no rush to raise its benchmark interest rate target at its next policy announcement on Jan. 9.

In fact, there are expectations the central bank could wait several months before its next move due to the combination of several recent economic developments.

"With some of the volatility we've seen in the financial markets and the lower oil prices' impact on economic activity in Western Canada, the Bank of Canada can afford to be cautious and will be in no rush to their next rate hike," said James Marple, senior economist for TD Bank.

The Bank of Canada, which can raise its trend-setting rate as a way to keep inflation from climbing too high, has introduced five hikes since the summer of 2017 in response to the stronger economy.

Marple said the central bank's next increase might come in March — and that may only be if crude prices move back up, market volatility abates and trade fears surrounding the U.S.-China relationship start to subside.

"We only think they'll go twice this year," he said, referring to potential 2019 Bank of Canada rate hikes.

Statistics Canada said the recent drop in global oil prices translated into a 5.4 per cent price contraction at the gas pump in November, handing the gasoline category its first year-over-year decrease since June 2017.

Excluding gas, the inflation rate would have increased 1.9 per cent last month.

Leading up to the report, analysts had projected inflation to slow thanks to weeks of cheaper prices at the pump. Economists had expected a increase of 1.8 per cent, according to Thomson Reuters Eikon.

"Bad news for Alberta has been good news for Canadian consumers, as cheaper gasoline has brought inflation down to earth," CIBC chief economist Avery Shenfeld wrote in a note to clients.

Prices softened in other areas as well. The cost of durable goods recoiled 0.1 per cent last month, following a 0.9 per cent expansion in October, as consumers paid less for furniture, tools and other household equipment compared with a year earlier.

Downward pressure on prices last month also came from lower year-over-year costs for traveller accommodation, digital computing equipment and devices and telephone services.

The main upward forces driving inflation were higher costs for fresh vegetables, airline tickets and mortgage interest.

The average of the agency's three core inflation readings slowed slightly to 1.9 per cent last month, from two per cent in October.

All three core measures sat at 1.9 per cent — below the ideal two per cent target of the Bank of Canada. The core average has stayed close to the two per cent bull's-eye in recent months and November's reading is the first time it slowed to 1.9 per cent since June.

The Bank of Canada pays close attention to core inflation ahead of its rate decisions.

As governor Stephen Poloz weighs his next decision, experts expect him to remain focused on the recent plunge oil prices, the capacity of the energy sector to engage in business investment and the ability of Canadian households — many of which are saddled with very high levels of debt — to manage higher interest rates.

The bank must also consider another concern — a sharp deceleration in wage growth over the past six months. The national unemployment rate has been near a 40-year low for more than a year, but wage growth has cooled instead of picking up its pace in the tightened labour market.

stscan : Statistics Canada | bkcan : Bank of Canada

HD  Tanager Energy Announces Settlement of Litigation
CR Globenewswire 
WC 649 words
PD 19 December 2018
ET 09:40 AM
SN The Canadian Press
SC CPR
LA English
CY (c) 2018 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.

LP 

FOR: TANAGER ENERGY INC.

CALGARY, Alberta, Dec. 19, 2018 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Tanager Energy Inc. (“Tanager” or the “Corporation”) (TSX-V: TAN, OTCQB: TANEF) is pleased to announce that it has reached a settlement (the “Settlement”) with plaintiff William Robinson (the “Plaintiff”), ACH Management, LLC (“ACH”) and other parties involved in litigation concerning the ACH Credit Facility.

TD 

Pursuant to the Settlement, upon Tanager’s payment to the Plaintiff in the total amount of US$1,000,000, to be paid in equal installments over 4 months from January through April, 2019, the principal amount of the loan under the ACH Credit Facility in the amount of US$3,775,000, plus all accrued interest currently outstanding, shall be forgiven.

In addition, following payment in full to the Plaintiff, with respect to the securities of Tanager currently held by ACH, 9,765,000 common shares shall be transferred from ACH to the Plaintiff, and the remaining 11,235,000 common shares and 21,000,000 common share purchase warrants shall be cancelled, transferred or assigned as directed by Tanager.

Upon satisfaction of the Settlement terms and conditions, the ACH Credit Facility shall be terminated and all parties to the litigation shall be mutually released and discharged from any claims and causes of action related to the ACH Credit Facility and ACH’s common shares and common share purchase warrants.

Neither the TSX Venture Exchange nor its Regulation Services Provider (as the term is defined in the policies of theTSX Venture Exchange) accepts responsibility for the adequacy or accuracy of this release.

Tanager Energy Inc. is an oil and natural gas and mineral exploration company headquartered in Calgary, Alberta, with executive offices in Houston, Texas. The Corporation’s common shares are listed on the TSX Venture Exchange under the trading symbol “TAN” and on the OTCQB as “TANEF”

For further information please contact:

Tom M. Crain, Jr. Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer Phone: 713-922-1219 Email:

HD IFR JV Reaches Total Depth at TEC-11 and Provides Tecolutla Operational Update
CR Globenewswire 
WC 1255 words
PD 19 December 2018
ET 07:39 AM
SN The Canadian Press
SC CPR
LA English
CY (c) 2018 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.

LP 

FOR: INTERNATIONAL FRONTIER RESOURCES CORPORATION

CALGARY, Alberta, Dec. 19, 2018 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- International Frontier Resources Corporation (“IFR” or the “Company”) (TSX-V: IFR) (OTCQB: IFRTF) is pleased to announce that Tonalli Energia (“Tonalli”), IFR’s joint venture (JV) with Mexican petrochemical leader Grupo IDESA, has reached total depth at its first conventional horizontal well, (“TEC-11”), on its onshore Tecolutla block.

TD 

TEC-11

The TEC-11 field development horizontal well has been drilled to a depth of 3283 meters (m) Measured Depth (MD). The well was landed horizontally in the Cretaceous aged El Abra formation limestone. A total of approximately 670m of measured length of Cretaceous limestone was drilled before the total depth was reached. Oil shows were encountered during drilling.

A 4.5-inch production liner has been set and cemented to 2865m MD. Based on Logging While Drilling (“LWD”) Gamma Ray and Sonic log tools and drill cuttings descriptions, the cased portion of the TEC-11 well Is interpreted to be in an interval similar to what was produced in the offset TEC- 2 well.

Tonalli is currently planning a perforation, stimulation and flow-testing program for TEC-11. This program is expected to commence in the New Year following which Tonalli will provide a comprehensive update on the results of the production test.

TEC -10

Tonalli has now received its first payment from PEMEX for oil shipped from its Tecolutla field. Tonalli’s TEC-10 producing well averaged 156 barrels of oil per day in October and November at an approximate average crude sales price of USD$64.73 per barrel. Initial operating costs averaged USD$17.39 per barrel with an expectation that these costs will continue to be reduced as production moves from rented equipment to permanent facilities, improved water handling and operational efficiencies. Operating netbacks for the two months averaged USD$20.12 per barrel.

The Tecolutla field is located within the Tampico-Misantla basin, which has multiple reservoirs with diverse play types and access to existing infrastructure, market, service sector providers and an established supply chain. In 2017, IHS Markit identified the Tampico-Misantla Basin as a potential “Super Basin”.

Through its JV with Grupo Idesa, IFR was one of the first foreign companies to participate in Mexico’s historic reform of the oil and gas sector. The Tecolutla block was awarded to Tonalli as part of the first round and third call of Mexico’s oil and natural gas “mature fields” bid round (“Round 1.3”).

About International Frontier Resources

International Frontier Resources Corporation (IFR) is a Canadian publicly traded company with a demonstrated track record of advancing oil and gas projects. Through its Mexican subsidiary, Petro Frontera S.A.P.I de CV (Frontera) and strategic joint ventures, it is advancing the development of petroleum and natural gas assets in Mexico. The Company also has projects in Canada and the United States, including the Northwest Territories and Montana.

The Company’s shares are listed on the TSX Venture, trading under the symbol IFR and on the OTCQB under the symbol IFRTF. For additional information please visit .

For further information

 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
 
 Steve Hanson – President and CEO                                                                    or   Tony Kinnon – Chairman                                                                                     
 
 (403) 215-2780                                                                                           (403) 215-2780                                                                                             
 
 shanson@internationalfrontier.com[mailto:shanson@internationalfrontier.com]       tkinnon@internationalfrontier.com[mailto:tkinnon@internationalfrontier.com]

The forward-looking information is based on certain key expectations and assumptions made by IFR's management, including expectations concerning prevailing commodity prices, exchange rates, interest rates, applicable royalty rates and tax laws; capital efficiencies; decline rates; future production rates and estimates of operating costs; performance of existing and future wells; reserve and resource volumes; anticipated timing and results of capital expenditures; the success obtained in drilling new wells; the sufficiency of budgeted capital expenditures in carrying out planned activities; the timing, location and extent of future drilling operations; the state of the economy and the exploration and production business; results of operations; performance; business prospects and opportunities; the availability and cost of financing, labour and services; the impact of increasing competition; ability to market oil and natural gas successfully and IFR's ability to access capital.

SUBJECT: MIS

NEWS RELEASE TRANSMITTED BY Globe Newswire

Information:


CO

SE Politics
HD Politics Briefing: Ottawa making progress on drinking-water promise; Also: Another Canadian detained in China
BY Chris Hannay
WC 1230 words
PD 19 December 2018
SN The Globe and Mail (Breaking News)
SC GMBN
LA English
CY ©2018 The Globe and Mail Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Good morning. With official Ottawa winding down for the holidays, we thought we’d take this week to reflect back on the stories that shaped the year in politics. We asked some of the reporters in The Globe’s Ottawa bureau what stories they covered that had the biggest impact. Gloria Galloway [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/authors/gloria-galloway/] , who writes about many issues that affect Indigenous communities, chose a story that didn’t get much attention: drinking water.

The federal government is making headway in its efforts to ensure that all First Nations in Canada have access to clean drinking water.

TD 

The lack of potable water on many reserves has been one of those seemingly insurmountable challenges, and human-rights issues, that governments of both stripes have tried to tackle – with few results.

Engineering experts were skeptical when Prime Minister Justin Trudeau promised, during the 2015 election campaign, to end all of the long-term drinking water advisories on public systems on reserves within five years of a Liberal government taking office.

There were 105 advisories in effect at that time. Some, like the one in the Neskantaga First Nation in Northern Ontario, stretched back two decades.

In January, 2018, the Indigenous Services department added 250 First Nations water systems to the list of those it will repair and maintain. And, in doing so, it added 24 more long-term boil-water advisories to the total.

But, by mid-December of this year, the total number of advisories had been reduced to 64, and federal officials predicted that a few more would be cleared before the calendar rolls over to 2019.

That has been done with an investment of close to $2-billion, not all of which has been spent.

“We’re very happy with the progress in that we have been able to keep on track with our targets and our plan,” Jane Philpott, the Minister of Indigenous Services, said in an interview. “Though clearly,” she added, “there is a long way to go yet.”

Perry Bellegarde, the National Chief of the Assembly of First Nations, counts the progress being made in providing clean drinking water to First Nations communities as a success story.

The federal government predicts that most of the long-term advisories will end by 2020, and is on track to meet the 2021 promise. Ms. Philpott said there is a plan in place for each of the communities that remain on the list.

This is the daily Politics Briefing newsletter, written by Chris Hannay [http://twitter.com/channay] in Ottawa. It is available exclusively to our digital subscribers. If you’re reading this on the web, subscribers can sign up for the Politics newsletter [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/newsletters/?utm_source=Arcnewsletter&utm_medium=onsite&utm_campaign=fixed_positions&utm_term=signuppage&utm_content=politics_promo] and more than 20 others on our newsletter signup page. Have any feedback? Let us know what you think [mailto:channay@globeandmail.com] .

TODAY’S HEADLINES

The chairman of Chinese telecom giant Huawei says his company has been the victim of politics, as Western spy agencies warn the company could pose a national security threat to other countries. “If you have proof or evidence, it should be made known,” Ken Hu said at a rare press conference[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-huawei-chair-demands-evidence-of-national-security-risk/] in Shenzhen. Huawei’s chief financial officer, Meng Wanzhou, was arrested at a Vancouver airport earlier this month on behalf of U.S. authorities, who allege she committed fraud. Ms. Meng has denied any wrongdoing. Friends of Ms. Meng have put up $3-million[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-a-real-estate-agent-and-a-former-huawei-worker-are-among-sureties-for/] as part of her bail.

Another Canadian has been detained[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-china-detains-third-canadian-in-wake-of-huawei-cfos-arrest-global/] in China, but the Global Affairs department says they don’t believe this case has anything to do with the two Canadians who had been arrested in retaliation for Canada’s arrest of Ms. Meng.

Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer says Canada should show disapproval of Saudi Arabia’s regime by cutting oil imports[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-scheer-opposes-ending-saudi-arms-deal/] , not by touching a multibillion-dollar weapons export.

At a pretrial hearing for the case of Vice-Admiral Mark Norman, a member of the Forces testified that his boss told him to get around access-to-information requests[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-armed-forces-avoided-using-mark-normans-name-left-no-record-trail/] by never using Mr. Norman’s name in e-mails.

Processing periods in RCMP forensics labs are hitting new records for long turnaround times[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-rcmps-forensic-firearm-testing-backlog-adding-delays-to-justice/] in the years since many labs were closed.

Today’s update on the new parliamentary chambers: Senators say they pointed out a design flaw[https://www.hilltimes.com/2018/12/19/design-flaw-new-senate-chamber-flagged-senators-two-years-ago-says-committee-chair/181639] two years ago that is now delaying the opening of the new Senate by a few weeks, but the architects just wouldn’t listen to them.

And for those who work near Parliament Hill, a head’s up: Those lime-green accessories that security officers have been wearing are going out of style. As part of a labour dispute[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-parliamentary-security-protests-get-more-colourful-amid-stalled-labour/] , the officers are stepping up their dress-code violations, with promises of more to come in January.

Campbell Clark (The Globe and Mail)[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-trudeaus-16-billion-oil-and-gas-assistance-package-wont-heal/] on the federal government’s aid package for Alberta’s oil-and-gas sector: “The long-term solution to Alberta’s problems is a new pipeline. Right now, that’s not in Mr. Trudeau’s gift, because even though his government bought the Trans Mountain pipeline for a cool $4.5-billion, the expansion project is blocked by a court ruling that forces Ottawa to redo consultations with First Nations along the route.”

Katie Ragan (Montreal Gazette)[https://montrealgazette.com/opinion/opinion-quebecers-and-albertans-should-set-aside-provincialism] on the two solitudes: “Quebec’s contempt and Alberta’s anger are understandable. But for projects in the country’s overall economic and social interest, Canadian provinces need to stop thinking so provincially. For Quebec, that means being open to pipelines that meet safety and environmental standards for the sake of benefits to all Canadians ­ like the ability to build more schools, hospitals, roads, and hydro-electricity infrastructure. For Alberta, that means recognizing that equalization payments are at the core of the Canadian Confederation, which continues to aspire to leave no member of the federation behind.”

Bessma Momani (The Globe and Mail)[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-cancelling-canadas-saudi-arms-deal-would-merely-be-a-feel-good/] on Canada’s $15-billion arms deal with Saudi Arabia: “Stopping the war is vital, but it is important to put Canadian LAV sales into perspective. Saudi Arabia’s primary arms supplier is the United States; trailing way behind is the United Kingdom and France. According to the Stockholm International Peace and Research Institute’s arms transfer database, the military capability value of Canadian arms transfers – or its actual contribution to Saudi fighting capability – is practically insignificant. In fact, arm sales to Saudi Arabia from countries such as Switzerland, Spain and Italy are more important to the Saudi war machine than Canada’s contribution.”

John Ibbitson (The Globe and Mail)[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-why-doug-ford-is-not-mike-harris/] on two Ontario Progressive Conservative premiers: Mike Harris and Doug Ford: “Things are so different under Mr. Ford that it’s hard to believe he leads the same political party. Killing the cap-and-trade carbon pricing without also cutting spending led to the credit downgrade. Whatever spending has been cut, such as to midwifery training or an Indigenous arts program, seems designed more to spite opponents than help balance the books.”

SE National
HD Morning Update: The plan tearing a Nova Scotia town apart; Ford backs Taverner as OPP head; Also: The RCMP is taking longer to analyze firearms – and its adding delays to an already overburdened justice system
BY Arik Ligeti
WC 1675 words
PD 19 December 2018
SN The Globe and Mail (Breaking News)
SC GMBN
LA English
CY ©2018 The Globe and Mail Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Good morning,

These are the top stories:

TD 

A proposed pulp-mill discharge pipe is tearing a Nova Scotia town apart

A pulp and paper mill in Pictou says it needs to build a waste-discharge pipeline to stay in business – a plan that’s splitting[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-in-a-nova-scotia-town-an-effluent-pipeline-feud-puts-forestry-and/] families, neighbours and lifelong friendships (for subscribers). The main source of opposition is a group of local fishermen worried that sending the treated effluent into the Northumberland Strait could be detrimental to a prized fishing ground in a region where thousands work in the seafood industry. The mill also employs more than 200 people, and as many as 1,000 forestry workers rely on its operation. As tensions rise, cars have been scratched, threats have been made and police are on high alert. “People are nervous for their livelihood on both sides.” said Sean Fraser, the Liberal MP for the area.

This is the daily Morning Update newsletter. If you’re reading this on the web, or it was forwarded to you from someone else, you can sign up for Morning Update and more than 20 more Globe newsletters on our newsletter signup page [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/newsletters/?utm_source=Arcnewsletter&utm_medium=onsite&utm_campaign=fixed_positions&utm_term=signuppage&utm_content=morning_update_promo] .

Doug Ford says his family friend Ron Taverner will be the ‘best commissioner the OPP has ever seen’

The Ontario Premier’s comments[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-premier-doug-ford-says-he-looks-forward-to-ron-taverner-as-opp/] come as a review into the appointment gets under way after allegations of political interference were levelled at the Progressive Conservative government. Ford also took aim at Brad Blair, alleging without evidence that the Deputy Commissioner violated the Police Services Act when he publicly complained about Taverner’s appointment in a letter to the Ombudsman. Taverner is now back in his role at the Toronto Police Service as he awaits the results of the Integrity Commissioner’s review of whether Ford had a conflict in the hiring process.

Huawei’s chairman is calling for proof that his company is a pawn of Beijing

Ken Hu said Huawei[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-huawei-chair-demands-evidence-of-national-security-risk/] is a victim of “ideology and geopolitics” and challenged the U.S. and its allies to provide evidence the Chinese tech firm poses security risks (for subscribers). It’s the first time a such a senior figure at the company has directly addressed concerns China could use the firm to spy on or disable communications networks, a sign Huawei is worried the U.S. campaign is having an impact. Canada is currently conducting a review of Huawei to decide whether it will follow the U.S., Australia and New Zealand in barring the installation of the firm’s 5G equipment.

The RCMP is taking longer to analyze firearms – and its adding delays to an already overburdened justice system

The turnaround time[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-rcmps-forensic-firearm-testing-backlog-adding-delays-to-justice/] for routine firearms analyses at the RCMP’s forensics labs has reached 206 days, up from a 56-day average in 2013-14. So why does this matter? A 2016 Supreme Court limit that placed time limits on criminal trials means cases risk getting thrown out if they’re not completed in a speedy manner. “The one thing slowing us down is the lab,” said Crown attorney Rick Woodburn. “Forensic testing will take time, that’s understandable. But the numbers we’re seeing are terribly lengthy. It’s dramatically affecting our justice system.” Woodburn says more staff are needed and that the RCMP should consider reopening labs it shuttered during a round of cost-cutting.

Got a news tip that you’d like us to look into? E-mail us at tips@globeandmail.com [mailto:tips@globeandmail.com] Need to share documents securely? Reach out via SecureDrop [https://sec.theglobeandmail.com/securedrop/]

IN CASE YOU MISSED IT

The federal government is providing $1.65-billion in loans and aid to help the oil patch

The assistance[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-ottawa-offers-16-billion-boost-to-struggling-oil-sector/] is meant to help companies until more capacity to export crude is added over the next few years. The majority, $1-billion, will come in loans. The measures don’t include funds to help Alberta buy rail cars to move crude despite Premier Rachel Notley’s call for assistance on that front. (for subscribers)

Michael Flynn’s sentencing was abruptly postponed

Lawyers for U.S. President Donald Trump’s first national security adviser requested the delay[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/us-politics/article-michael-flynn-heads-to-sentencing-with-finals-jabs-at-the-fbi/] after a federal judge declared his “disgust” and “disdain” for Flynn’s crime of lying to the FBI. The postponement raises the prospect of further co-operation by Flynn to avoid or reduce time in prison.

Serial killer Dellen Millard was handed his third life sentence for first-degree murder

The 33-year-old Toronto man won’t be eligible for parole until he is 102. He has been convicted[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/toronto/article-dellen-millard-gets-third-life-sentence-for-killing-father-not-2/] of killing his father, a girlfriend and a total stranger all in a period of less than a year.

MORNING MARKETS

Markets rise

Global equity and crude oil markets attempted a tentative recovery[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/investing/markets/inside-the-market/market-news/article-premarket-after-plunge-world-stocks-try-to-claw-their-way-out-of/] on Wednesday after three days of sharp losses that saw investors seek out the safety of bonds amid mounting pessimism over world growth. Tokyo’s Nikkei lost 0.6 per cent, and the Shanghai Composite 1.1 per cent, while Hong Kong’s Hang Seng gained 0.2 per cent. In Europe, London’s FTSE 100, Germany’s DAX and the Paris CAC 40 were up by between 0.4 and 0.7 by about 6:20 a.m. ET. New York futures were up. Markets have been expecting the Fed to raise interest rates again this afternoon in the face of criticism from President Donald Trump. The Canadian dollar was close to 74 US cents.

WHAT EVERYONE’S TALKING ABOUT

To truly tackle the opioid crisis, governments need to work together

“Seventeen people a day are hospitalized with opioid-related poisonings. Supervised consumption site front-line workers – who endure stress and trauma in these volunteer roles – deserve the same benefits and support that other emergency medical personnel receive. Overdose hospitalization rates were 2.5 times higher in towns with 50,000 to 100,000 people than they were in larger cities. If governments want real, lasting solutions that address the sheer scale and growing scope of the crisis, they need to come together to make that happen through concrete government funding.” – Abdullah Shihipar [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-to-truly-tackle-the-opioid-crisis-governments-need-to-work-together/] (Masters of Public Health candidate) and Brandon D.L. Marshall (associate professor of epidemiology) at Brown University

What we can learn from St. Mike’s to keep our kids safe

“The St. Michael’s case has opened a window into the dangers of abuse that face children and youth across Canada in a variety of settings. With younger children, the safety imperatives can seem more obvious. We regulate things such as car seats and playground equipment. We teach children in our lives to look both ways when crossing the street. We child-proof our homes. When children become adolescents, they have new experiences that can sometimes present new risks. … Let’s start by losing our complacency and pledging to never permit, mask or make excuses for any type of abuse. Let’s call hazing and initiation what it truly is: a deliberate, often illegal use of power to abuse and degrade another human being.” – Peter MacKay [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-what-we-can-learn-from-st-mikes-to-keep-our-kids-safe/] (board chair) and Karyn Kennedy (CEO) of the Boost Child & Youth Advocacy Center

The year when recklessness ruled

“The worst is over. Probably. The Trudeau government survived the Donald Trump administration in 2018. Barely. But there is likely more madness and mayhem to come, and the frustration for Canadians in dealing with the United States remains. No matter the extent of the provocation, anti-Americanism isn’t an option. The economic ties are too strong. The year 2018 will go down as the most fractious and belligerent in bilateral relations since Confederation. Yes, there was the upheaval with Kennedy and Diefenbaker in the early 1960s, but that was over defence issues. Their antagonisms didn’t threaten to collapse the very architecture of the relationship – that being the trading regime.” – Lawrence Martin [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-the-year-when-recklessness-ruled/] (for subscribers)

LIVING BETTER

Opioids are no more effective for treating chronic pain than over-the-counter options, a study has found

The findings[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-opioids-no-more-effective-for-treating-pain-than-over-the-counter/] raise questions about how often the drugs are prescribed, given the risks they pose. The research also showed that the modest benefits provided by opioids seemed to wane over time, despite the fact that many patients stayed on the drugs for long periods.

MOMENT IN TIME

Robert Ripley’s first cartoon appears

Dec. 19, 1918: Long before anyone saw Mother Teresa’s face in a cinnamon bun, American Robert Ripley discovered a craving among the public for the weird and wonderful. Working at The New York Globe in the early 1920s as a sports cartoonist, Ripley’s first cartoon was a single-panel piece entitled Champs and Chumps that featured remarkable feats of athleticism. Later that year, the panel morphed into a wider look at oddities from the human and natural worlds, with Ripley asking the public to believe it – or not. Travelling to more than 200 countries, he collected offbeat facts and artifacts, which he displayed in his “Odditoriums.” (He seemed to have a particular penchant for farmyard mutations and items collected during his tours of the Far East.) Much of the material for the cartoon was sourced by the unheralded Norbert Pearlroth, his researcher for more than 50 years, who was fluent in 14 languages and spent most days at the New York Public Library scouring foreign publications. In 1929, Believe it or Not! was syndicated worldwide, making Ripley a household name and a millionaire. Today, Ripley Entertainment Inc. is owned by Vancouver’s Jim Pattison Group and boasts more than 100 attractions worldwide. – Ian Morfitt

If you’d like to receive this newsletter by e-mail every weekday morning, go here [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/newsletters/?utm_source=Arcnewsletter&utm_medium=onsite&utm_campaign=fixed_positions&utm_term=signuppage&utm_content=morning_update_promo] to sign up. If you have any feedback, send us a note [mailto:aligeti@globeandmail.com] .
